policy_name: Policy on AI and Academic Work

schools: Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences

statement: Harvard's commitment to intellectual rigor requires that all academic work represents the student's genuine understanding. While AI tools offer legitimate learning opportunities, their use must be transparent and responsible.
guiding_principles: Authenticity: Your work must reflect your own thinking and analysis
Integrity: Academic honesty is foundational to Harvard's reputation
Responsibility: You are accountable for all submitted work
Transparency: Disclose AI use clearly and completely
Learning: AI should enhance education, not replace learning

permitted_uses.description: Using AI to explore ideas, test hypotheses, and develop approaches
examples: Using ChatGPT to explore multiple perspectives on a topic
Using AI to brainstorm research methodology
Using AI to test problem approaches

permitted_uses.description: Using AI as educational tool to comprehend difficult concepts
examples: Using ChatGPT to explain challenging material
Using AI to work through example problems
Using AI to see alternative problem-solving approaches
permitted_uses.note: May be required if incorporated into submitted work

permitted_uses.description: Using AI to find, organize, and summarize academic sources
examples: Using AI to organize literature and identify patterns
Using AI to summarize key research findings
Using AI to identify relevant articles in a field

permitted_uses.description: Using AI for grammar, clarity, organization, and style editing
examples: Using AI writing assistants for proofreading
Using AI to improve clarity and coherence
Using AI to organize arguments logically

permitted_uses.description: Using AI for programming, data analysis, and visualization
examples: Using AI for code generation with review
Using AI to generate statistical visualizations
Using AI to suggest appropriate analysis methods

permitted_uses.description: Using AI tools for accessibility and learning accommodations
examples: Using AI to transcribe lecture notes
Using AI to simplify complex text for accessibility
Using AI-powered research tools with documented need

prohibited_practices.practice: Submitting AI Output as Own Work
examples: Submitting ChatGPT-written essay without disclosure
Turning in AI-generated analysis as your analysis
Using AI-written code without acknowledging tool
prohibited_practices.consequence: Violation of Harvard Honor Code; range of sanctions including failing grade, suspension, dismissal

prohibited_practices.definition: Using AI when instructor explicitly prohibits it
prohibited_practices.why_prohibited: Disrespects learning objectives and course requirements
examples: Using AI on examination (proctored or take-home marked 'no AI')
Using AI on assignment marked 'individual work'
Using AI when instruction clearly states 'without AI assistance'
prohibited_practices.consequence: Failing grade on assignment/course, Honor Code violation

prohibited_practices.definition: Using AI to generate false content presented as authentic
examples: Creating fake experimental data
Generating non-existent citations
Using AI to invent quotations
prohibited_practices.consequence: Serious Honor Code violation; suspension or dismissal likely

prohibited_practices.definition: Submitting AI-generated work you don't understand
prohibited_practices.why_prohibited: Circumvents skill development central to education
examples: Submitting AI code you cannot explain
Using AI analysis you haven't verified
Relying entirely on AI to avoid learning required skills
prohibited_practices.consequence: Honor Code violation; failing grade or reassessment requirement

disclosure_requirements.when_required: Any substantive AI use in submitted work

methods.template: AI Disclosure: I used [Tool Name] [dates] for [specific purposes]. The AI generated [description of output], which I [modified/verified/integrated as follows]. This disclosure ensures transparency and acknowledges AI as a tool rather than the source of ideas.
# Generated by [AI Tool] - [date] / modified as described in disclosure
Data analysis was conducted using [software] with [AI tool] assistance for [specific task]. All results were independently verified by [verification method].

required_information: Tool name and version (e.g., ChatGPT-4, GitHub Copilot 1.88)
Specific purposes (brainstorming, code generation, proofreading, etc.)
Extent of use (portions vs. entire work; iterative use)
Modifications made (what you changed, verified, or improved)
Any uncertainty or limitations in AI output

course_communication: Clearly state AI policy in course syllabus (permitted, prohibited, conditional)
Specify whether policy varies by assignment type
Provide concrete examples of acceptable and unacceptable AI use
Explain how AI use relates to learning objectives
in_class_discussion: Discuss AI capabilities and limitations with students
Share how to properly disclose AI use
assessment_design: Design assessments that require genuine understanding demonstration
Include varied assessment types (presentations, viva voce, group work)
Use assessments that require explanation and reasoning
Consider whether exam/take-home format affects AI permission
evaluation_considerations: Use plagiarism detection as supporting evidence, not sole determinant
Consider student's demonstrated understanding in class
Evaluate writing consistency with known student voice
Compare current work to student's prior work patterns
responding_to_concerns: Interview student about work and process (non-accusatory)
Ask student to explain methodology and reasoning
Request follow-up assignment if understanding unclear
Use formal procedures before escalating to Honor Council

the_honor_code.relevant_provision: Academic integrity is fundamental to all work submitted for credit
implications: Violating assignment-specific restrictions violates the Honor Code
All work must represent your genuine understanding
the_honor_code.reporting: Suspected violations should be reported to Resident Dean or dean@college.harvard.edu
the_honor_code.process: Formal Honor Council hearing process is available

student_resources: Writing Center: assistance with writing and organization
Accessibility Office: support for students with documented needs
Academic Integrity course: detailed guidance on ethical academic work
Instructor office hours: discuss AI policy and expectations specific to your course

frequently_asked_questions.q: Can I use ChatGPT to write my essays?
frequently_asked_questions.a: No. You should write the analysis and arguments yourself. AI can assist with brainstorming, organizing ideas, and editing. You must disclose any AI use and it should not constitute the main content.
Generally yes for CS and engineering courses, with disclosure and understanding verification. You must be able to explain all code you submit. Check with your instructor.

frequently_asked_questions.q: What if I use AI but don't disclose?
frequently_asked_questions.a: That constitutes a violation of the Honor Code. Transparency about AI use is essential. When in doubt, disclose.

frequently_asked_questions.q: Can I be punished for disclosing AI use?
frequently_asked_questions.a: No. Disclosure of appropriate AI use will not result in penalties. Better to disclose than to conceal. If use violates assignment requirements, instructor can give feedback.
